In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Public financial management (PFM) in Papua New Guinea (PNG) has deteriorated since 
its  independence  and  limits  the  Government’s  ability  to  deliver  services.  The  2008–2009 
midterm review of the PNG country strategy and program 2006–2010 confirmed that PFM would 
remain  one  of  the  program’s  key  focal  areas.1 PFM  is  also  central  to  the  Government’s 
strategies, particularly through the Public Sector Reform Program, which underpins the medium-
term development strategy by seeking to create the conditions and capacity for the Government 
to deliver its development objectives, institutions, and systems. PFM reform efforts are focused 
through the public expenditure review and rationalization process, which is a joint government–
development partner program coordinated by the multiagency public expenditure review and 
rationalization implementation committee. Moreover, initiatives to enhance aid effectiveness are 
set out in the 2008 PNG Commitment on Aid Effectiveness,2 which localizes the 2005 Paris 
Declaration on Aid Effectiveness.3 
 
2.  The technical assistance (TA) is intended to help strengthen PFM in PNG by enhancing 
oversight of statutory authorities, improving project evaluation and prioritization, strengthening 
procurement  arrangements,  enhancing  transparency  and  monitoring  of  subnational  service 
delivery, and supporting the development of domestic bond markets. The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.4 In conceptualizing the assistance, consultations were conducted 
during the country strategy and program midterm review with particular consultations on the TA 
concept paper during 25 February–9 March 2009. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Following a decade of deterioration, the country’s PFM arrangements improved from 
2004–2008—albeit from a low base. The Government has pursued a PFM reform program 
since 2003, when PNG was emerging from a recession and public finances were under serious 
strain due to poor fiscal discipline, weak expenditure management, and a high debt burden. A 
2008 public expenditure and financial accountability (PEFA) assessment confirmed progress in 
several  PFM  areas.5 Macroeconomic  stability  improved  as  budget  surpluses  have  been 
achieved since 2004, the debt burden is lower and more balanced, and a proportion of windfall 
revenues were set aside for future use. Budget preparation is more orderly, transparent, and 
consultative, and headway has been made on clearing public accounts’ backlogs.  
 
4.  Despite  these  improvements,  PFM  remains  weak,  thus  impeding  the  Government’s 
ability to control expenditures, disburse the budget as approved, and provide essential services. 
Fundamental  arrangements  are  in  place,  but  implementation  weaknesses  mean  that  the 
systems and procedures for expenditure and payroll control cannot be relied upon to ensure 
appropriate accountability. Transparency in budget execution is weak, with budget integrity 
undermined by unauthorized diversion of funds (including resources for regional development). 
Hence,  it  is  difficult  to  track  expenditures  to ensure  the budget  is delivered  as  approved. 
Oversight has been weakened by delays in preparing and releasing public accounts and audit 
reports. Statutory authority accountability is particularly weak.

5.  As a consequence of the global economic crisis, PFM systems are likely to be tested 
while  adjusting  to  more  austere  fiscal  conditions.  With  tighter  fiscal  constraints,  project 
evaluation and prioritization will be critical, as will robust procurement systems to ensure results 
are delivered. PNG’s fiscal decentralization program has accelerated in recent years, thus 
placing  increased  service  delivery  responsibilities  on  provinces  and  districts.  Improving 
development outcomes will depend on strengthening subnational PFM systems. The global 
economic crisis is also putting pressure on PNG’s continued progress in reducing net foreign 
currency debt. Market conditions do not currently favor issuing a bond denominated in local 
currency, but this is likely to change. In the meantime, planning and preparations can be 
undertaken. The TA is intended to support responses to these issues in the five areas outlined 
below. 
 
6.  Statutory authority governance. First, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) provided 
assistance  in  2007–2008  to  review  statutory  authority  governance  arrangements. 6  Two 
consultants worked under the guidance of a Treasury-led interagency working group, which was 
established to provide project guidance. The consultants’ report concluded that although the 
statutory authority framework appears quite rigorous according to international norms, it has 
significant  weaknesses.  In  response,  the  report  recommended  (i)  creating  a  public  body 
classification methodology; (ii) strengthening Part VIII of the Public Finances (Management) Act, 
1995 to require performance agreements between the minister and the public body, enhancing 
enforcement powers regarding noncompliance, and incorporating guidelines for establishing 
public bodies; (iii) enhancing monitoring capacity within central agencies; (iv) introducing annual 
performance agreements between boards and responsible ministers; and (v) an orderly and 
rigorous process for establishing or restructuring public bodies. The interagency working group 
is working on items (i), (ii), and (v) and has requested ADB support to move forward on items (iii) 
and (iv). 
 
7.  Investment evaluation and prioritization. Second, the Department of Treasury (the 
Financial  Evaluation  Division  and  the  Structural  Policy  and  Investments  Division)  and  the 
Department  of  National  Planning  and  Monitoring  undertake  investment  evaluation  and 
prioritization.  Guidance  is  not  readily  available  for  preparing  and  reviewing  economic  and 
financial analyses of potential investment projects, however, and not all responsible officials are 
conversant with the application of relevant tools and techniques. Budget availability, particularly 
due to constraints as a result of the economic and financial crisis, will make it even more critical 
to have tools and techniques for appraising potential public investments. The Department of 
Treasury currently faces severe staffing constraints, which limits its ability to discharge its 
functions, but it will shortly recruit up to 53 new officers, a significant portion of whom will have 
some  responsibility  for  evaluating  projects.  The  Department  of  Treasury  has  sought  ADB 
assistance to strengthen project appraisal capacity. 
 
8.  Procurement.  Third,  while  the  procurement  framework  is  reasonably  sound, 
implementation is problematic. For instance, contract finalization may take upwards of a year 
during which time contractors may no longer be available, costs may have altered significantly, 
and the operating environment may have changed. The Central Supply and Tenders Board 
(CSTB) plays a lead role in procurement processes. Through the 2005 Paris Declaration on Aid 
Effectiveness,  the  Accra  Agenda  for  Action,  and  the  2008  PNG  Commitment  on  Aid 
Effectiveness, the Government and development partners have agreed to work together to 
strengthen and use government systems, including systems for procurement. ADB already 
relies on government systems for procurement, but there is scope for improvement. ADB and 
the World Bank jointly prepared a country procurement assessment report (CPAR) in 2003,

3
which  was  updated  in  2006,  and  identified  a  range  of  recommendations.  A  Procurement 
Engagement  Group  has  also  been  established  to  improve  procurement  arrangements  and 
practices. Chaired by the CSTB, the group comprises development partners, including ADB, as 
members. Further progress is being made with the establishment of an Australian Agency for 
International  Development-supported  project  management  unit,  which  is  working  with  the 
Department of Prime Minister and the National Executive Council to improve the timeliness of 
contract awards. The PNG Commitment on Aid Effectiveness tasks the Government, the CSTB, 
and development partners (led by the World Bank) with updating the CPAR.7 The European 
Commission also intends to undertake an institutional procurement assessment as it considers 
whether to provide budget support. The ADB Central Operations Services Office conducted 
regional procurement training in PNG in November 2009. 
 
9.  Service  delivery.  Fourth,  PNG  is  increasingly  decentralizing  service  delivery 
responsibilities to poorly resourced provincial and local governments. The capacity of provincial 
and  local  governments  to  administer  and  implement  projects  will  need  to  be  enhanced 
significantly  if  increased  expenditure  is  to  translate  into  improved  public  service  delivery. 
Improving development outcomes will depend on addressing PFM system problems at the 
subnational level. Service delivery has improved with support from the Service Improvement 
Program, which is being implemented by the Public Sector Reform Management Unit within the 
Department of Prime Minister and the National Executive Council. Nevertheless, much more 
remains to be done. Among other things, there is a need to improve monitoring and tracking of 
basic service delivery outcomes. The National Economic and Fiscal Commission (NEFC) has 
made significant progress in tracking public provincial expenditures that has helped to identify 
impediments and promote ways to improve essential service delivery. In the last 3 years, the 
Government has significantly increased funding to the district level through the District Services 
Improvement  Program,  which  places  increasing  strains  on  already weak  PFM  systems.  In 
particular, the Government has significantly raised its grants for development spending to K14 
million ($5.04 million) for each of PNG’s 89 districts. ADB has begun piloting, on a limited basis 
within three selected districts, surveys to evaluate the service delivery. There is an opportunity 
to upscale this initiative based on the pilot’s results. 
 
10.  Domestic  debt  market  development.  Fifth,  financial  markets  (arguably)  facilitate 
economic development through more efficient allocation of capital.8 In that connection, the 
Government  has  made  consistent  efforts  in  recent  years  to  develop  the  bond  market. 
Information provision has improved, average tenors have increased, and the government bond 
yield curve now extends to 15 years. In 2007, the Department of Treasury (Financial Evaluation 
Division) established the PNG Bond Market Development Project. As part of these efforts, the 
Government has requested ADB assistance to develop the policy framework for potential listing 
of government securities on the Port Moresby Stock Exchange and the development of the 
secondary market as a whole. The Government has also expressed interest in ADB’s local 
currency loan product because this would support the medium-term debt strategy objective of 
reducing net foreign currency debt and contribute to the objectives of the PNG Bond Market 
Development Project. ADB and the Government have held discussions since late 2006, when 
the ADB Treasury Department visited PNG to discuss with authorities the prerequisites and 
processes for a kina-denominated bond issue. The Government requested ADB to consider the 
feasibility of such an issue in August 2008.

11.  These  five  activities  are  demand-driven  and  support  ADB’s  ongoing,  broad-based 
engagement in PFM.9 The activities are also intended to support ADB’s operations, both current 
and future. The proposed work on strengthening oversight of statutory authorities recognizes 
that the Government is increasingly devolving functions to statutory authorities in sectors where 
ADB is active (for example, the National Roads Authority and potentially the Civil Aviation 
Authority). As such, efforts to strengthen statutory authority monitoring are of direct relevance to 
ADB. In addition, improved project evaluation and prioritization and improved procurement 
practices are directly relevant to the preparation and implementation of ADB-supported projects. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The proposed TA is intended to strengthen PFM arrangements and contribute to more 
efficient  and  effective  public  administration—more  specifically  toward  delivering  better 
governance through improved transparency, accountability, and efficiency in managing and 
using public resources. This is to be achieved through targeted interventions in five priority 
areas. Performance will be measured primarily through updated CPAR and PEFA assessments, 
as well as by joint ADB–World Bank annual country performance assessments. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  Strengthened oversight of statutory authorities. The TA will work with the Treasury-
led interagency working group to (i) identify and seek participation in the exercise of 10 pilot 
statutory authorities,10 (ii) review available information and information systems, (iii) agree to key 
performance  indicators  and  identify  any  additional  information  requirements,  (iv)  work  with 
agencies  to  design  and  establish  the  enhanced  monitoring  process,  and  (v)  identify 
requirements and approaches for extending the enhanced monitoring process. 
 
14.  Improved project evaluation and prioritization. The TA will work with the Treasury 
and the Department of National Planning and Monitoring11 to (i) prepare guidance materials for 
economic and financial analysis of investment projects, (ii) develop three case studies of project 
analysis that are relevant to the PNG setting, and (iii) conduct four workshops on project 
analysis and project financing approaches. 
 
15.  Improved procurement practices. The TA will support ADB’s efforts, in conjunction 
with the Government and other development partners, to strengthen procurement arrangements 
and practices. ADB’s Central Operations Services Office will participate in this process. 
 
16.  Enhanced subnational service delivery monitoring. Based on the outcome of an 
existing ADB-supported pilot study of service delivery, it is proposed that the TA will support

upscaling this pilot. This will involve refining the survey instrument and methodology, as well as 
extending the survey to 10 selected districts. Districts will be chosen in areas where ADB is 
actively engaged, such as the highlands provinces. District sample selection will also take into 
consideration the income groupings of provinces to which districts belong. This would be in line 
with NEFC’s income classification of provinces based on their revenue-generating capacity. 
Working with NEFC, the purpose of the surveys will be to track services actually delivered 
against the recorded expenditures. 
 
17.  Domestic debt market development. The TA will work with Treasury and the Bank of 
PNG to identify issues requiring resolution prior to any proposed issuance of an ADB-backed 
kina-denominated bond. The TA will also develop the policy framework for potential listing of 
government securities on the Port Moresby Stock Exchange and development of the secondary 
market as a whole. This will include considering institutional, regulatory, taxation, and legal 
arrangements. A detailed road map toward a local currency bond issue and toward creation of a 
secondary bond market will be prepared and agreed. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,100,000 equivalent, of which $1,000,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan, to cover 
consulting services, report production, and miscellaneous administrative and workshop costs. 
The Government will provide the remaining $100,000 equivalent as in-kind contributions to 
cover office accommodation and support services (Appendix 2). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  The Department of Treasury will be the executing agency and implementing agency for 
statutory  authority  oversight  and  domestic  debt  market  development  components.  The 
Department of National Planning and Monitoring will be the implementing agency for the project 
evaluation component. CSTB and NEFC will be the implementing agencies, respectively, for the 
procurement and for the service delivery survey activities. In addition to the Department of 
Treasury, the TA will be implemented in close cooperation with the Department of Finance, 
Department of National Planning and Monitoring, Department of Prime Minister and National 
Executive Council (Public Sector Reform Management Unit), CSTB, and development partners. 
 
20.  International  consultants  (29  person-months)  and  national  consultants  (12  person-
months) will be engaged with expertise in economic and financial analysis, statutory authority 
governance, procurement, bond market development, and legal and financial management. 
Outline  terms  of  reference  are  provided  in  Appendix  3.  ADB  will  engage  an  international 
consulting firm using the quality-based selection method and through requesting simplified 
technical proposals in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as 
amended from time to time). The proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in line with the Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook.12 The TA is expected to be implemented over 36 months 
commencing in January 2010 and finishing in December 2012. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  Papua  New  Guinea  for  Supporting  Public  Financial  Management,  and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Team Leader and Financial Analyst (international, 9 person-months) 
 
1.  The team leader will have at least 10 years of experience in preparing financial analyses of 
organizations and investment projects in various sectors, as well as significant training experience. 
He or she will hold a qualification in finance or a related discipline. Experience in Pacific developing 
countries  is  highly  desirable.  The  financial  analyst  will  work  in  close  collaboration  with  the 
Department of National Planning and Monitoring and the Department of Treasury (Structural Policy 
and Investment Division) on (i) project appraisal with the economic analyst, and (ii) statutory 
authority monitoring with the statutory authority expert. 
 
2.  Overall leadership and management. The team leader will coordinate the work of all 
consulting team members. More specifically, the team leader will (i) prepare and distribute brief 
monthly work plan updates to ADB and to the executing agency and other stakeholders; (ii) ensure 
that the TA is implemented according to the work plan, terms of reference, and consultancy 
contract provisions; (iii) incorporate any subsequent instructions and guidance agreed upon with 
ADB and the executing agency; (iv) ensure the timely preparation of all required reports—including 
an inception report, midterm report, draft final report, and final report—in a format satisfactory to 
the executing agency and ADB; (v) coordinate organization of the training workshops; and (vi) take 
responsibility for the collective work of the consulting team, as well as for coordinating and liaising 
with stakeholders. 
 
3.  Technical  activities.  In  close  collaboration  with  the  economic  analyst  to  ensure  that 
activities  are  coordinated,  and  particularly  regarding  the  preparation  of  case  studies  and 
arrangements for training workshops, the financial analyst will undertake the following specific 
tasks in relation to project appraisal: (i) identify and obtain appropriate and available guidance 
materials for project financial analysis, such as ADB’s Financial Management and Analysis of 
Projects;1 (ii)  prepare  three  sectoral  case  studies  relevant  for  Papua  New  Guinea  (PNG)  of 
financial management and analysis (e.g., for a transport sector project, energy sector project, and 
social sector project); (iii) prepare and deliver four workshops on project financial management and 
analysis, which will be structured to cater for varying levels of attendee expertise; and (iv) provide 
where  reasonably  requested  advice  on  financial  management  and  analysis  issues.  In  close 
collaboration  with  the  statutory  authority  expert  to  ensure  that  activities  are  coordinated,  the 
financial  analyst  will  undertake  the  following  specific  tasks  in  relation  to  statutory  authority 
monitoring: (i) review available information and information systems, (ii) agree on key performance 
indicators for pilot statutory authorities and identify any additional information requirements, (iii) 
work with the interagency working group and pilot statutory authorities to design and establish the 
enhanced monitoring process, (iv) arrange and conduct two workshops on monitoring processes, 
and (v) identify requirements and approaches for extending the enhanced monitoring process. 
Outputs will include (i) 30 copies of guidance materials on financial management appraisal and 
analysis,  (ii)  three  case  studies  of  financial  management  appraisal  and  analysis,  (iii)  four 
workshops on financial management appraisal and analysis, (iv) two workshops on monitoring 
processes, and (v) enhanced monitoring reports for the pilot statutory authorities. 
 
2.  Economic Analyst (international, 4 person-months)

analyses of investment projects in various sectors and significant training experience. He or she

3.  Project Finance Expert (international, 1 person-month) 
 
7.  The project finance expert will have at least 10 years of experience in structuring project 
financing transactions in various sectors and significant training experience. He or she will hold a 
qualification in finance or a related discipline. Experience in Pacific developing countries is highly 
desirable. The project finance expert will work in close collaboration with the financial analyst, the 
economic analyst, the Department of National Planning and Monitoring and the Department of 
Treasury (Structural Policy and Investment Division). 
 
8.  In close collaboration with the financial and economic analysts to ensure that activities are 
coordinated,  and  particularly  regarding  the  preparation  of  case  studies  and  arrangements  for 
training workshops, the project finance expert will undertake the following specific tasks: (i) identify 
and obtain appropriate and available guidance materials on project finance; and (ii) prepare and 
deliver in an interactive and practical manner two workshops presentations and case studies on 
project financing operations. 
 
9.  Outputs will include (i) 30 copies of guidance materials on project financing, and (ii) two 
workshops on project financing operations.

highly desirable. The statutory authority expert will work in close collaboration with the Department 
of Treasury (Structural Policy and Investment Division) and with the financial analyst.

collaboration with the financial analyst: (i) review available information and information systems, 
(ii) agree on key performance indicators for pilot statutory authorities and identify any additional 
information  requirements,  (iii)  work  with  the  interagency  working  group  and  pilot  statutory

5.  Survey Coordinator (international, 2 person-months) 
 
13.  The  survey  coordinator  will  have  at  least  8  years  of  experience  in  designing  and 
implementing village surveys, preferably in the Pacific islands and related to service delivery. The 
coordinator will provide guidance on refining the survey instruments and methodology that were 
tested during the service delivery pilot survey phase. The coordinator will undertake the following 
tasks under the direction of the country economist (Papua New Guinea Resident Mission): (i) 
review pilot phase survey design and methodology and recommend improvements, and (ii) prepare 
a note that details suggestions and recommendations from the pilot survey review. 
 
6.  Procurement Expert (international, 4 person-months)  
 
14.  The procurement expert will have at least 10 years of experience in procurement policies 
and  practices.  Experience  with  procurement  systems  in  several  jurisdictions  is  required. 
Experience in Pacific developing countries is highly desirable, as are knowledge of and experience 
with ADB procurement policies and practices, procurement harmonization efforts, and procurement 
diagnostic  tools  (such  as  the  Organisation  for  Economic  Co-operation  and  Development—
Development Assistance Committee methodology for assessing national procurement systems). 
The procurement expert will review all relevant literature including the Papua New Guinea country 
procurement assessment report3 and procurement procedures and practices published by the 
Auditor-General’s Office.4 
 
15.  The procurement expert will undertake the following tasks in conjunction with the Central 
Supply and Tenders Board (CSTB) and other development partners: (i) liaise with procurement 
stakeholders  and  provide  ADB  input  to  multiagency  procurement  initiatives,  including  the 
Procurement  Engagement  Group;  and  (ii)  provide  support  to  the  CSTB  on  ADB-related 
procurement matters. 
 
7.  Bond Issuance Expert (international, 3 person-months) 
 
16.  The bond issuance expert will have at least 8 years of experience in bond issuance and an 
advanced degree in finance or a related discipline. Familiarity with ADB’s local currency loan 
products is highly desirable and experience in emerging markets is essential. The bond issuance 
expert will undertake the following tasks in conjunction with the Department of Treasury (Financial 
Evaluation Division) and the Bank of PNG, and with support from the legal expert: (i) review 
institutional, regulatory, taxation, and legal arrangements having potential implications for a bond 
issue and listing of government securities on the stock exchange; (ii) formulate proposals to 
address potential issues; (iii) conduct two stakeholder workshops to provide background on ADB’s 
local currency product, advise on process, and review identified issues and proposed responses; 
(iv) prepare a road map for the potential issue of a local currency bond, listing of government 
securities on the stock exchange, and creation of a secondary bond market which identifies the

8.  Legal Expert (international, 1 person-month) 
 
17.  The legal expert will have at least 8 years of experience in financial market arrangements 
and will be legally qualified to practice in one or more leading financial centers. Experience in 
emerging  markets  is  essential.  In  conjunction  with  the  bond  issuance  expert,  Department  of

for a bond issue and listing of government securities on the stock exchange; and (ii) formulate

9.  Financial Analysis Expert (national, 6 person-months) 
 
18.  The national financial analysis expert will have at least 5 years of experience in preparing 
financial analyses of organizations and investment projects and will hold a qualification in finance 
or a related discipline. The national financial analysis expert will assist the international financial 
analyst with the following specific tasks: (i) identify and obtain appropriate and available guidance 
materials for project financial analysis, such as the ADB Financial Management and Analysis of 
Projects  (footnote  1);  (ii)  prepare  three  PNG-relevant  sectoral  case  studies  of  financial 
management and analysis (e.g., for a transport sector project, energy sector project, and social 
sector project); (iii) prepare and deliver four workshops on project financial management and 
analysis, which will be structured to cater for varying levels of attendee expertise; and (iv) provide, 
where reasonably requested, advice on financial management and analysis issues.  
 
10.  Financial Management Expert (national, 6 person-months) 
 
19.  The national financial management expert will have at least 5 years of experience in 
financial management or auditing and will hold an accounting qualification. The national financial 
management expert will assist the international statutory authority expert with the following specific 
tasks:  (i)  review  available  information  and  information  systems;  (ii)  agree  key  performance 
indicators for pilot statutory authorities and identify any additional information requirements; (iii) 
work with the interagency working group and pilot statutory authorities to design and establish the 
enhanced monitoring process; (iv) arrange and conduct two workshops on monitoring processes;
